docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Despite the advances made in educating the public and policy makers about mental illness, some of the responses by business interests noted in your article illustrate that there is work to do (front page, April 30).

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Thank you, Pete Harnisch and Frank Rich, for bringing out in the open once again the realities of someone suffering from clinical depression (''Harnisch's Perfect Pitch,'' column, May 1). I felt as if I was ''coming out of the closet'' when I began to admit to friends and co-workers that I was clinically depressed.

headline.kicker: Mentally Ill Needn't Make Workplace Inefficient

docs.lead_paragraph: Just 96 hours after celebrating a bipartisan agreement to balance the Federal budget, Republicans and Democrats started squabbling today over details of the provisions affecting Medicare. The disputes did not imperil the overall agreement, but illustrated the problems sure to bedevil the process of translating the accord into law.

headline.main: Medicare Rift Becomes Sequel Of Earlier Budget Agreement

docs.abstract: Democratic and Republican lawmakers, after celebrating bipartisan agreement to balance Federal budget, start squabbling over provisions affecting Medicare; disputes do not imperil overall agreement, but illustrate problem of translating accord into law (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Oxford Health Plans Inc. said it is experiencing further delays processing bills and will advance $110 million to appease some New York hospitals with unpaid claims. Oxford, an operator of managed health care plans, said the delays have been worsened by the New York Health Care Reform Act. That legislation, which took affect on Jan. 1, forced managed-care companies to pay for certain graduate medical education and indigent care in the state.

docs.lead_paragraph: Health insurance for some people who buy their own policies could become less expensive if a bill released yesterday by the Assembly Insurance Committee becomes law. The bill would make the rules for individual health care coverage similar to those for small-group plans, which allow insurers to charge different rates based on factors like age, sex and geographic location. All individual policyholders under 65 now pay the same rates, leading to higher premiums for younger people, according to the bill's sponsor, Scott Garrett, a Sussex County Republican.

docs.lead_paragraph: As Bob Manning descended a utility pole near the St. Lawrence Seaway one cold February afternoon, a jolt of electricity sent him flying. The novice lineman, a young father with a pregnant wife, hit the pavement head first. Now Mr. Manning, paralyzed from the neck down, is trying to collect his workers' compensation benefits.

headline.main: Paralyzed Since Fall in 1962, Man Is Still Seeking Benefits

docs.abstract: Paralyzed Since Fall In 1962, Man Is Still Seeking Benefits** Article describes legal saga of 62-year-old former utility lineman Bob Manning, who has been unsuccessful in efforts to collect workers' compensation benefits since falling from utility pole in 1962 and becoming quadriplegic; even though he has won awards, largest being $1.2 million, they have been tied up in litigation ever since, making case probably longest unresolved workers' compensation issue on record; Utilities Mutual Insurance Company, insurer for Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, Manning's former employer, says it has no obligation to pay anything until appeals are exhausted; at heart of case is whether company can be forced to pay for round-the-clock nursing care Manning receives from wife, who is registered nurse; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Robert A. Beck, who rose from door-to-door selling to the top position at the Prudential Insurance Company of America, died yesterday at his home in Vero Beach, Fla. Mr. Beck, who also had a home in Rumson, N.J., was 71. The cause was cancer of the esophagus, his son, Stephen, who lives in Manhattan, said.

headline.main: Robert A. Beck, 71, Dies; Former Head of Prudential

docs.lead_paragraph: Women who belong to local health maintenance organizations have 68 percent more out-of-pocket expenses than men because things like contraceptives and screenings for osteoporosis are not covered in most managed care networks, according to a report released yesterday by Representative Charles E. Schumer.

headline.main: Report Says H.M.O.'s Treat Women Unfairly
headline.kicker: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK CITY

docs.lead_paragraph: In Austin, Tex., construction had to be halted for several months during the nesting season of the golden-cheeked warbler. In Dallas, a construction accident killed three people because workers had not been properly trained.

headline.main: Crews Are Scarce To Put Up Towers For New Digital TV

docs.abstract: Few companies that build television towers are embarking on crash program across country to build hundreds of towers under federally mandated schedule to usher in digital high-definition television--timetable that construction industry says may be impossible to meet; only about half-dozen crews have experience to put up these towers, which, at heights up to 2,049 feet, are taller than world's tallest buildings; diagram (M)
docs.snippet: In Austin, Tex., construction had to be halted for several months during the nesting season of the golden-cheeked warbler.    In Dallas, a construction accident killed three people because workers had not been properly trained.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE sun glistened on Long Island Sound one day last fall, as an unlikely group gathered on shore at the former Cilco Terminal on Bridgeport Harbor. Bankers, business people, civic leaders and even a few members of Congress, all in business attire, mingled with longshoremen in jeans and T-shirts. Over a celebratory lunch of hamburgers and sodas, they listened as speakers, one by one, praised an unusual partnership. The longshoremen had bought both the terminal and its New Haven counterpart, in the process rescuing the two ports from bankruptcy, saving hundreds of jobs and sweetening Connecticut's commercial prospects. Halfway through the speeches, a voice came over the public address system reminding the longshoremen that the lunch hour was over. A Colombian cargo ship full of bananas needed unloading, so off went the new owners, leaving behind their party and distinguished guests.

headline.main: Two Ports, Hundreds of Jobs, Saved in Unusual Pact

docs.abstract: International Longshoremen's Association local, in world's first-ever employee acquisition of port, has bought New Haven and Bridgeport, Conn, terminals with top managers of New Haven Terminal through their newly formed Coastline Terminals Inc; deal involves employee stock option plan backed by $10 million bank loan, Connecticut Development Authority guarantee and long-term lease on terminals from Logistec Stevedoring; rescued two ports from bankruptcy, saving hundreds of jobs; photos (L)
